title: Smith drops f-bomb after India catch controversy
text:
Angry Smith drops f-bomb 1:15 Steve Smith left fuming after Murali Vijay’s grassed catch was reversed and given not out 12 minutes ago by Staff Writers Source: FOX SPORTS AUSTRALIAN skipper Steve Smith has been left furious after Murali Vijay ran off the field to prepare to bat again, before being sent back to the slips following replays that showed the catch he claimed was grassed. 
Vijay and India thought it had dismissed the Australian side after No. 11 Josh Hazlewood edged off-spinner Ravi Ashwin to Vijay at gully. 
But as Vijay sprinted off the field to prepare to chase Australia’s total, video replays — which had been requested by the umpire — showed that the ball had made contact with the ground just after hitting Vijay’s hands. 
Upon the ‘not out’ decision, an angry Smith looked out at the field and appeared to mouth the words “f***ing cheat” from the Australian dressing room, before slumping back into his chair. 
The comment was quickly picked up on social media, with video spreading quickly. 
The not out decision didn’t prolong Australia’s innings too much longer, with Ashwin claiming Hazlewood two balls later, trapping the Aussie pace bowler LBW for a nine-ball duck. 
It is the latest flashpoint in what has been a spiteful series, in which Smith himself was accused of systemic cheating by the Indian team. 
The Australian captain was central when frustrations boiled over during the second Test in Bengaluru, when he was caught looking up at the team dressing room when pondering whether to review an lbw dismissal. Steve Smith gestures for a DRS decision. Source: AFP 
Indian captain Virat Kohli reacted angrily on field, and didn’t hold back in the press conference that time — though notably stopped short of calling Smith a cheat. 
Instead he simply strongly inferred it. 
“There’s a line that you don’t cross on the cricket field, sledging and playing against the opponents is different,” Kohli said after India’s victory in Bengaluru. 
“I don’t want to mention the word, but it falls into that bracket. 
“I would never do something like that on the cricket field.” 
When asked if the word he was referring to was “cheating”, Kohli replied: “I didn’t say that, you did”. 
The fallout was vicious, with the boards of both teams coming out swinging in defence of their captains. 
The fourth Test has endured far less controversy, but it was reignited late on day three as Australia’s chances of victory continued to fade.
